questions.text: An ultrasound of a 24-year-old woman shows an endometrium with a classic trilaminar appearance, as seen in the image provided. Which phase of the menstrual cycle does this ultrasound image most likely represent?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Late Proliferative

 

  • The trilaminar (three-layered) appearance of the endometrium on ultrasound is characteristic of the late proliferative (pre-ovulatory) phase of the menstrual cycle. This phase features a hypoechoic central layer (functional zone), sandwiched by two hyperechoic layers representing the basal layer and interface with the uterine cavity.
  • This pattern develops under the influence of rising estrogen levels before ovulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Secretory: In this phase, the endometrium becomes more uniformly hyperechoic and thicker, losing the trilaminar pattern due to progesterone effect.

 

Option B. Early proliferative: The endometrium is thinner and more homogenous, without a distinct trilaminar pattern.

 

Option C. Menstrual: The endometrium is thin or irregular, often disrupted with low echogenicity, reflecting shedding of the lining.

questions.text: An 80-year-old male's autopsy reveals ventricular thickening and abnormal aggregations of protein filaments arranged in beta-pleated sheets within the ventricular walls. Bone marrow examination shows no evidence of plasma cell dyscrasia. The abnormal protein aggregations are most likely composed of which of the following?

A 34-year-old female is undergoing tubal ligation, and the procedure illustrated in the image is performed. Which of the following methods best describes the surgical technique used in this procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parkland method

 

  • The image shows the Parkland method of tubal ligation, a widely used technique for permanent female sterilization. 
  • In this method, a segment of the fallopian tube is tied on both ends and excised. The procedure involves:
    1. Grasping the isthmic portion of the fallopian tube.
    2. Placing two ligatures (sutures) around the tube at a specific site.
    3. Excising the segment of the fallopian tube between the ligatures.
  • The Parkland method is effective, safe, and minimizes the risk of fistula formation since only a small portion of the tube is removed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pomeroy method: In the Pomeroy method, the fallopian tube is tied and a loop is formed, which is then excised. It is a simpler procedure but less commonly performed compared to the Parkland method.

 

Option C. Irving method: The Irving method involves tying the fallopian tube, then burying the proximal end in the uterine wall and the distal end in the broad ligament. It is not depicted in this image.

 

Option D. Uchida method: The Uchida method involves injecting the mesosalpinx with saline to dissect the tube away from its mesentery before ligation and excision. This is not the method shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Parkland method of tubal ligation involves ligating and excising a segment of the fallopian tube to provide permanent sterilization. 
  • It is a common and effective surgical technique with a low risk of complications, making it a preferred method in many cases.

questions.text: A 30-year-old housewife accidentally spilled hot tea on herself at a kitty party. She develops a lesion, which is very painful, erythematous and shows blistering. Which parts of the skin are affected in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Epidermis + superficial dermis

 

  • The lesion is characteristic of a second-degree superficial partial-thickness burn, where the epidermis and superficial dermis are affected. 
  • These burns are erythematous, painful, and often associated with blisters. 
  • The presence of pain indicates that nerve endings are still intact, which is consistent with superficial dermal involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epidermis: This describes a first-degree burn (e.g., sunburn), which is limited to the epidermis and presents with redness and pain but no blistering.

 

Option C. Epidermis + whole dermis: This describes a deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burn, which involves both the epidermis and entire dermis. These burns may be less painful due to nerve destruction and often appear leathery or charred.

 

Option D. Whole skin + connective tissue, muscle, bone: This describes a fourth-degree burn, which extends through the skin into deeper structures such as muscle or bone. These burns are painless due to complete nerve destruction and are associated with significant tissue loss.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Second-degree superficial partial-thickness burns involve the epidermis and superficial dermis, presenting with erythema, pain, and blisters. 
  • These burns are painful due to preserved nerve endings in the dermis.

A 36-year-old male presents with complaints of increased urination and thirst. His medical history is notable for a non-functional pituitary adenoma. After two hours of water deprivation, and following desmopressin (antidiuretic hormone analog) administration, his lab results are as follows. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Central diabetes insipidus

 

  • Central diabetes insipidus is characterized by a persistently low urine osmolality despite water deprivation, which significantly improves after desmopressin administration. This indicates a deficiency of antidiuretic hormone (ADH), as seen in this patient.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Primary polydipsia: Incorrect. In primary polydipsia, urine osmolality would normalize after water deprivation without the need for desmopressin.

 

Option B. Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus: Incorrect. In nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, the kidneys are unresponsive to ADH, and desmopressin would not significantly increase urine osmolality.

 

Option C. Diabetes mellitus: Incorrect. Diabetes mellitus causes polyuria and polydipsia due to osmotic diuresis from hyperglycemia. Serum osmolality and urine osmolality patterns seen here are not consistent with diabetes mellitus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In central diabetes insipidus, urine osmolality remains low after water deprivation but increases significantly with desmopressin administration, confirming ADH deficiency as the underlying issue.

questions.text: A 26-year-old nulligravida presents with primary amenorrhea. She is diagnosed with 46XY gonadal dysgenesis. During pelvic laparoscopy, what is the expected finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Streak gonads and female internal genitalia

 

  • In 46XY gonadal dysgenesis (also known as Swyer syndrome), individuals have a 46XY karyotype but the gonads fail to develop properly and become streak gonads (non-functional, fibrous tissue). 
  • Due to the absence of functional testes, these individuals do not produce adequate amounts of testosterone or anti-Müllerian hormone (AMH, also known as Müllerian-inhibiting factor), which allows for the development of female internal genitalia (uterus, fallopian tubes, and upper vagina).
  • Despite having a Y chromosome, the lack of functional testicular tissue and corresponding hormone production leads to the female phenotype (female external genitalia and internal female reproductive organs).
  • The streak gonads have no hormonal function, which is why patients often present with primary amenorrhea.
  • Laparoscopy would reveal streak gonads and female internal genitalia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Streak gonads and male internal genitalia: This is incorrect because the absence of functional testes and Müllerian-inhibiting factor (AMH) means that female internal genitalia will develop, not male internal genitalia.

 

Option C. Empty pelvis (no gonads or internal genitalia): This is incorrect. The patient will have streak gonads and female internal genitalia, such as a uterus and fallopian tubes.

 

Option D. Bilateral abdominal testes and male internal genitalia: This describes Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS), where individuals with 46XY have abdominal testes but no functional female internal genitalia. This is not the case in Swyer syndrome, where there are streak gonads and female internal genitalia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In 46XY gonadal dysgenesis (Swyer syndrome), the expected findings on laparoscopy are streak gonads and female internal genitalia. 
  • This condition occurs due to the failure of gonadal development and the absence of sufficient testosterone and Müllerian-inhibiting factor (AMH), resulting in a female phenotype despite the 46XY karyotype.

A 25-year-old pregnant woman undergoes routine ultrasound, which reveals the fetal presentation shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Frank breech

 

  • Frank breech is the most common type of breech presentation and is characterized by the fetus presenting with its buttocks first, with the hips flexed and knees extended (legs pointing upward). 
  • This description matches the fetal presentation shown in the image, where the legs are extended upwards while the buttocks are positioned to deliver first. 
  • Frank breech presentation is commonly identified during prenatal ultrasound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Incomplete breech: Incomplete breech refers to a situation where one or both hips are not fully flexed, and one or both feet may present first. This is not consistent with the image, as the fetus in the image has its hips flexed, and the feet are not presenting.

 

Option C. Stargazer breech: Stargazer breech, also called hyperextended breech, involves a fetus with an extended neck and the face positioned upwards toward the maternal abdomen. This is not seen in the image, as the neck is in a normal, flexed position.

 

Option D. Footling breech: Footling breech is characterized by one or both feet presenting first, with the hips and knees extended. This presentation is inconsistent with the image, where the legs are extended upward and the feet are not presenting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Frank breech presentation involves the fetus presenting with its buttocks first, hips flexed, and knees extended (legs pointing upward).
  • It is the most common breech presentation and must be differentiated from other breech types, such as complete breech (hips and knees flexed) and footling breech (feet presenting).

questions.text: A 32-week pregnant woman presents in preterm labor. Antenatal corticosteroids are being considered to promote fetal lung maturity. In which of the following conditions should corticosteroids not be administered?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chorioamnionitis

 

  • Chorioamnionitis is an intrauterine infection involving the amniotic sac and fetal membranes.
  • Administering antenatal corticosteroids in the presence of chorioamnionitis is generally contraindicated because steroids may exacerbate the infection by suppressing maternal immune responses. 
  • The focus in chorioamnionitis is on immediate delivery to reduce maternal and fetal risks, not prolonging pregnancy for fetal lung maturity.
  • In contrast, antenatal corticosteroids are beneficial in most other conditions associated with preterm labor as they accelerate fetal lung development and reduce the risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, intraventricular hemorrhage, and necrotizing enterocolitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Severe anemia: Severe anemia is not a contraindication to corticosteroid use. Although anemia may complicate pregnancy, corticosteroids remain essential in preterm labor to promote fetal lung maturity and reduce neonatal complications. The management of anemia should proceed alongside corticosteroid administration.

 

Option B. Prolonged rupture of membranes for more than 24 hours: Even with prolonged rupture of membranes, antenatal corticosteroids can be administered to improve fetal outcomes unless there is evidence of chorioamnionitis. The risk of infection does not outweigh the benefits of improving fetal lung maturity in most cases.

 

Option D. Pregnancy-induced hypertension: Pregnancy-induced hypertension is not a contraindication to corticosteroid administration. In fact, it is one of the conditions where steroids are often used to prepare the fetus for preterm delivery due to maternal or fetal complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Antenatal corticosteroids are used to promote fetal lung maturity in preterm labor and reduce neonatal complications.
  • They are contraindicated in cases of chorioamnionitis due to the risk of exacerbating intrauterine infection.

questions.text: What is the most likely cause of sudden vision loss without fundal glow in a patient without a history of trauma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitreous hemorrhage

 

  • Vitreous hemorrhage is characterized by sudden loss of vision and absence of fundal glow without a history of trauma. 
  • This occurs because blood in the vitreous cavity blocks light from reaching the retina, preventing visualization of the fundus and causing vision loss. 
  • The sudden onset and lack of fundal glow are key diagnostic features of vitreous hemorrhage.

 

 

Causes of Vitreous hemorrhage: 

 

  • Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (PDR)
  • Eales Disease
  • Central Retinal Vein Occlusion (CRVO)
  • Post trauma 

 

Treatment:

 

Initial Step: Patients should maintain a propped-up position to help settle the blood within the eye.

 

Natural Resolution: Wait for the hemorrhage to clear up spontaneously, as many cases resolve without intervention.

 

Surgical Treatment: If the hemorrhage does not resolve naturally and vision remains impaired, a vitrectomy may be performed. This surgery involves removing the blood-filled vitreous and replacing it with a saline solution to restore the eye's shape and function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute congestive glaucoma: While this can cause sudden vision loss, it typically doesn't result in complete loss of fundal glow. The fundus may appear hazy due to corneal edema, but it's usually still visible to some extent.

 

Option C. Optic atrophy: This condition leads to gradual vision loss rather than sudden loss. Moreover, the fundus and optic disc would still be visible during examination, allowing for clear visualization of the atrophied optic nerve.

 

Option D. Acute anterior uveitis: This primarily affects the front part of the eye and doesn't typically cause sudden, severe vision loss or loss of fundal glow unless there are extensive inflammatory membranes in the pupillary area.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Sudden loss of vision combined with absence of fundal glow, without a history of trauma, is highly characteristic of vitreous hemorrhage. 
  • This condition requires prompt evaluation to determine the underlying cause, which could include proliferative diabetic retinopathy, Eales disease, central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO), or other vascular abnormalities of the retina

A 35-year-old man with a history of RTA with intense pain in the suprapubic region. On examination, abdominal distention was present. Heart rate and blood pressure was normal. Imaging is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
Identify the eye condition depicted in the image provided.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute Anterior Uveitis

 

  • The image shows the characteristic hypopyon and precipitates on the corneal endothelium indicative of acute anterior uveitis, a form of eye inflammation that affects the front part of the uvea and primarily involves the iris and ciliary body. 
  • The presence of fine keratic precipitates and possibly cells in the anterior chamber, along with the visible inflammatory signs, supports this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Keratoconus: Typically presents with a cone-shaped deformation of the cornea and thinning that does not include the signs of inflammation shown in the image.

 

Option B. Fuchs' endothelial dystrophy: Marked by corneal guttata and thickening of the Descemet's membrane, leading to corneal edema but not accompanied by hypopyon or such extensive precipitates.

 

Option D. Corneal ulcer: While involving inflammation, it usually shows more corneal clouding due to infection or trauma, and the presentation would include more aggressive erosions or lesions, distinct from the pattern shown.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Acute anterior uveitis manifests with symptoms like redness, pain, photophobia, and vision changes, with clinical signs including keratic precipitates and possible hypopyon as shown in the image. 
  • Prompt identification and treatment are vital to prevent complications such as glaucoma, cataracts, or permanent vision loss.

Which of the following sodium transporters are present maximally in early part of PCT?

 

  1. Na-K-ATPase
  2. Na-glucose cotransport
  3. Na-H antiporter
  4. Na-HCO3 symporter
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3

 

  • In early PCT, sodium is reabsorbed with glucose (SGLT), via Na-H exchanger, and Na-K-ATPase drives the process.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. 3, 4, 1: Includes HCO3 symporter, which is more distal.

 

Option B. 4, 2: Incomplete set.

 

Option D. 1, 4: Misses glucose and H+ exchange.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a one-week history of diffuse abdominal pain. Her temperature is 39.1°C (102.3°F). Physical examination shows numerous scars and excoriations along both arms, scleral icterus, and tender hepatomegaly. Serum studies shown below:

 

 

Which of the following is least likely to be seen in the liver biopsy of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ground glass hepatocytes

 

  • Acute Hepatitis B infection: Biopsy shows ballooning degeneration of hepatocytes, spotty/focal necrosis, Councilman bodies (apoptotic hepatocytes), and confluent necrosis in severe cases.
  • Ground glass hepatocytes are a feature of chronic Hepatitis B infection due to HBsAg accumulation in hepatocyte endoplasmic reticulum.
  • Since the patient is in acute hepatitis (anti-HBc negative → very early), ground glass cells will not be seen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ballooning degeneration: Common in acute hepatitis, due to hepatocyte swelling and cytoskeletal damage.

 

Option C. Focal or spotty necrosis: Hallmark of acute viral hepatitis → scattered hepatocyte necrosis with lymphocytic infiltration.

 

Option D. Confluent necrosis of hepatocytes: Severe form in acute viral hepatitis, may progress to bridging necrosis and liver failure.

questions.text: What condition is commonly associated with the presence of scintillating scotoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Migraine

 

  • Scintillating scotoma is most commonly associated with migraine, particularly migraine with aura. 
  • This visual phenomenon typically appears as a shimmering or flickering light in the visual field and may precede or accompany a migraine headache. 
  • The scotoma usually expands over time and may be accompanied by other sensory disturbances.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypertension: While severe hypertension can cause visual symptoms due to retinopathy, it does not typically cause scintillating scotoma.

 

Option C. Transient ischemic attacks (TIAs): TIAs can lead to various visual disturbances due to reduced blood flow to the brain, but scintillating scotoma is more specific to migraine.

 

Option D. Myasthenia gravis: This autoimmune condition affects muscle strength, and while it can impact the muscles controlling eye movements leading to ptosis and diplopia, it does not cause scintillating scotoma.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Scintillating scotoma is a distinctive visual disturbance linked primarily to migraine with aura, serving as an important diagnostic clue for healthcare providers. 
  • Recognizing this symptom is crucial for differentiating migraine with aura from other neurological disorders.

questions.text: A patient presented with weakness of the right side of the face with loss of pain and temperature. Additionally, he experienced a loss of pain and temperature sensation in their left leg. The probable location of the lesion is:
For which of the following conditions is McCall culdoplasty commonly performed?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Enterocele repair

 

  • McCall culdoplasty is a surgical technique commonly performed during enterocele repair. 
  • Enteroceles occur when the peritoneal sac containing small bowel or other abdominal contents protrudes into the vaginal canal through a weakness in the vaginal apex or posterior vaginal wall.
  •  McCall culdoplasty involves obliteration of the cul-de-sac (pouch of Douglas) and reattachment of the uterosacral ligaments to reinforce the vaginal apex and prevent recurrence of the prolapse.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rectocele repair: Rectocele repair is performed to correct a bulge of the rectum into the posterior vaginal wall. This is managed with posterior colporrhaphy, not McCall culdoplasty.

 

Option B. Vault prolapse repair: Vault prolapse repair addresses prolapse of the vaginal apex following hysterectomy. It is often treated with sacrocolpopexy or uterosacral ligament suspension rather than McCall culdoplasty.

 

Option C. Urethrocele repair: Urethrocele repair involves correction of a prolapse of the urethra into the anterior vaginal wall, typically addressed with anterior colporrhaphy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • McCall culdoplasty is a procedure performed during enterocele repair to obliterate the cul-de-sac and prevent recurrence of the prolapse.
  • It strengthens the support structures of the vaginal apex by reattaching the uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the OPD due to increased fatigue and weight gain over the past 6 months. He has hypertension controlled with a calcium channel blocker. Two years ago, the patient's physical examination was unremarkable, and his blood tests, including a lipid panel, were normal. Blood pressure is 135/98 mm Hg, and pulse is 62/min. BMI is 28 kg/m2. On physical examination, the thyroid appears to be mildly enlarged and is irregular and firm in consistency. Laboratory studies reveal elevated TSH, low free thyroxine (T4), high total and LDL cholesterol, and mildly elevated triglyceride levels. questions.solution: Ans. B) Decreased LDL receptor gene expression

questions.text: The visual field defect shown in the provided image, caused by which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Olfactory groove meningioma

 

  • The visual field defect depicted — the junctional scotoma (JS) refers to ipsilateral central field loss in one eye and contralateral superotemporal field loss from involvement of ipsilateral optic nerve fibers and crossing inferior nasal fibers from the opposite side— is characteristic of a lesion affecting the optic chiasm or areas impacting the optic nerve fibers that correspond to the lower visual field of each eye. 

  • This pattern can be typically associated with a mass effect from an olfactory groove meningioma, which may compress the optic chiasm from below or slightly anteriorly, disproportionately affecting crossing fibers from the lower retinal quadrants (representing the upper visual field). 

  • This results in a visual field defect in the upper quadrant.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Glaucoma: Incorrect. Glaucoma typically presents with peripheral vision loss initially, rather than quadrant-specific anopsia. 

 

Option B. Anterior ischemic optic neuropathy: Incorrect. This condition generally causes a more diffuse or altitudinal field loss due to ischemia of the optic nerve head, not quadrant-specific loss. 

 

Option D. Syphilitic meningitis: Incorrect. While syphilitic meningitis can cause a variety of cranial nerve impairments including optic neuropathy, it does not typically present with such localized quadrant anopsia without other neurological signs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The junctional scotoma of Traquair (JST) is named after Harry Moss Traquair, a Scottish ophthalmologist known for his contributions to the field of perimetry.
  • Junctional scotoma of Traquair are visual field defects that arise from damage to the junction of the optic nerve and the optic chiasm. 
  • Sellar masses including pituitary tumors are the most common cause of these visual field defects. 
  • Ophthalmologic findings include ipsilateral central scotoma and typically a contralateral superior temporal visual field defect. 
  • An olfactory groove meningioma as a potential cause of upper quadrant anopsia due to its characteristic compression of the optic chiasm, affecting fibers that represent the upper visual field.

Which of the following parameters is most likely increased compared to a child with normal cardiopulmonary function?
Which of the following glucose transporters is located on the basolateral (contraluminal) side of the intestinal epithelial cells?

A 45-year-old male presents with fatigue, night sweats, and weight loss. A complete blood count (CBC) is performed, and the peripheral blood smear shows the presence of cells with increased basophilic cytoplasm, granulocytic precursors, and a high percentage of blasts. A bone marrow biopsy is performed. Which of the following is the most appropriate investigation for this patient's condition?

A 40-year-old female is brought to the emergency department with a 24-hour history of confusion. Her temperature is 38.9ºC, and examination reveals scleral icterus. Peripheral blood smear is shown below. Which of the following additional laboratory findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Elevated serum creatinine

 

  • This patient likely has thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), a condition characterized by the pentad of thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (schistocytes on smear), fever, neurologic symptoms, and renal dysfunction. Elevated serum creatinine indicates renal involvement, which is a common finding in TTP due to microvascular occlusion and ischemia.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Decreased serum phosphorus: Incorrect. Phosphorus levels are not typically decreased in TTP. Phosphorus abnormalities are more associated with endocrine or electrolyte disturbances rather than microangiopathic hemolysis.

 

Option B. Decreased serum potassium: Incorrect. Hemolysis in TTP can release intracellular potassium, leading to hyperkalemia, not hypokalemia.

 

Option C. Elevated serum bicarbonate: Incorrect. Elevated bicarbonate is not a feature of TTP. Acidosis, rather than alkalosis, may be present in severe cases of ischemic injury or sepsis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) is a medical emergency characterized by thrombocytopenia, hemolytic anemia, and end-organ damage, including renal dysfunction, as evidenced by elevated creatinine. Early recognition and treatment with plasma exchange therapy are critical.

choices.text: Exploration of CBD and Insertion of T- tube

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady presented with abdominal pain, vomiting, and jaundice. USG reports showed cholelithiasis. She underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Intraoperatively, stones were detected in the CBD. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Exploration of CBD and Insertion of T- tube

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient presents with gradual, progressive visual field loss in both eyes. Fundus is shown below. Which cell type in the retina is primarily affected in this patient's condition?

A 42-year-old male presents with difficulty in coordinating his eye movements, particularly when attempting rapid shifts in gaze (saccades). Neurological examination suggests dysfunction in the cerebellum. Which of the following cerebellar nuclei is most likely responsible for controlling these saccadic eye movements?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fastigial Nucleus

 

  • The fastigial nucleus, located within the cerebellum, plays a critical role in coordinating saccadic eye movements by interacting with brainstem nuclei responsible for gaze control. 
  • It ensures proper timing and execution of rapid eye movements. 
  • The fastigial nucleus is particularly important in maintaining gaze stability during rapid head movements and contributes to balance and postural control as well.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dentate Nucleus: This nucleus is primarily involved in planning, initiation, and precision of voluntary motor activities, especially those related to distal limb movements. It does not control saccadic eye movements.

 

Option C. Emboliform Nucleus: Part of the interposed nuclei, it plays a role in motor coordination but is not directly involved in eye movement control.

 

Option D. Globose Nucleus: Also part of the interposed nuclei, this structure is involved in regulating more refined motor control but does not specifically coordinate saccadic eye movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The fastigial nucleus of the cerebellum is responsible for controlling saccadic eye movements and maintaining gaze stability. 
  • Its role is critical in coordinating rapid, precise eye movements in conjunction with other parts of the cerebellum and brainstem.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man, a retired banking executive with a history of smoking is admitted in ward with shortness of breath. Interpret the acid base disorder based on the arterial blood gas analysis report mentioned below. pH – 7.30, PCO2 -65 mm Hg, PO2 -60 mmHg, HCO3 - 36 mEq/L.
Identify the incorrect pair of staging systems

During fetal monitoring in labor, an increase in fetal heart rate acceleration is observed, indicating fetal well-being. Which of the following mechanisms is primarily responsible for this increase in fetal heart rate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Autonomic brainstem regulation

 

  • Fetal heart rate accelerations are a sign of fetal well-being, primarily mediated by autonomic brainstem regulation, which reflects the fetal central nervous system's responsiveness and oxygenation.
  1. Autonomic nervous system role:
    • Fetal heart rate accelerations are modulated by a balance between sympathetic and parasympathetic (vagal) activity.
    • During movement or stimulation, increased sympathetic activation causes transient heart rate accelerations.
    • Intact autonomic regulation is a reassuring sign of a well-oxygenated fetus.
  2. Clinical relevance:
    • The presence of heart rate accelerations on fetal monitoring is a good prognostic indicator and correlates with normal acid-base status.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aortic baroreceptors: Aortic baroreceptors detect changes in blood pressure and contribute to fetal heart rate modulation. However, baroreceptors are primarily involved in decelerations (in response to increased blood pressure) rather than accelerations.

 

Option C. ANP: Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) regulates fluid balance and blood pressure. It does not directly influence fetal heart rate accelerations.

 

Option D. Carotid body chemoreceptors: Carotid chemoreceptors respond to changes in oxygen, carbon dioxide, and pH levels, typically leading to heart rate decelerations in response to hypoxia. They do not play a primary role in fetal heart rate accelerations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fetal heart rate accelerations during labor are primarily mediated by autonomic brainstem regulation, reflecting fetal well-being and intact oxygenation.
  •  The presence of accelerations is a reassuring sign on fetal monitoring.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with fatigue and pallor. Her lab work shows low hemoglobin and microcytic hypochromic red blood cells. Free erythrocyte protoporphyrin and TIBC are elevated. What is the likely diagnosis?

When considering a patient with lung cancer, the imaging studies have measured the tumor size at 2.5 cm not invading in to the main bronchus. According to the TMN staging system, which stage would be appropriate for this patient?

A 26-year-old pregnant woman at 20 weeks' gestation presents with vaginal bleeding for the past few hours. She denies passage of any tissue or clots and is hemodynamically stable. On physical examination, the external cervical os is open, but no products of conception are visible at or beyond the os. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Inevitable abortion

 

  • Inevitable abortion is characterized by vaginal bleeding and an open cervical os without passage of products of conception. 
  • In this case, the pregnancy is still intrauterine, but the open os signifies that miscarriage is imminent.
  • The distinguishing feature is the open cervical os in the absence of expelled fetal or placental tissue, which confirms the diagnosis.
  • This condition is non-viable and typically requires medical or surgical intervention to manage the pregnancy loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incomplete abortion: Incomplete abortion involves vaginal bleeding with the expulsion of some but not all products of conception. On examination, products of conception may be visible at or near the cervical os or within the vaginal canal. This is inconsistent with the clinical scenario where no products of conception are noted.

 

Option B. Missed abortion: Missed abortion refers to intrauterine fetal demise without symptoms of expulsion. The cervical os is typically closed, and the patient may present with either an asymptomatic loss of fetal cardiac activity noted on ultrasound or delayed recognition of fetal demise. This does not match the clinical picture of vaginal bleeding and an open os.

 

Option C. Complete abortion: Complete abortion is defined by the complete expulsion of all products of conception, resulting in cessation of bleeding and cramping. The cervical os is closed on examination. In this scenario, the absence of tissue expulsion and an open os rule out this diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Inevitable abortion is diagnosed when vaginal bleeding occurs in conjunction with an open cervical os without expulsion of products of conception. 
  • This condition indicates an imminent miscarriage, and the pregnancy is no longer viable. 
  • The distinguishing feature is the open os in the absence of tissue expulsion.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing modified radical neck dissection (MRND) for laryngeal malignancy. While ligating the internal jugular vein, his etCO2 dropped from 40 mmHg to 14 mmHg, and the patient developed hypotension along with cardiac arrhythmia. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
An adult male presented with a duodenal ulcer is offered various surgical options for its treatment. Which of the surgical options listed below causes the least complications?

A 30-year-old patient with a history of inflammatory bowel disease presents with symptoms of abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea. A colonoscopy and biopsy are performed to distinguish between ulcerative colitis and Crohn’s disease. Which of the following morphological features would best help differentiate ulcerative colitis from Crohn’s disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diffuse distribution of pseudopolyps

 

  • Pseudopolyps are a hallmark of ulcerative colitis, resulting from regenerating mucosal tissue surrounded by areas of ulceration. 
  • This diffuse pattern of pseudopolyps is more characteristic of ulcerative colitis than Crohn’s disease, which typically presents with patchy, segmental lesions (“skip lesions”) rather than a continuous or diffuse involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucosal edema: While mucosal edema can occur in both ulcerative colitis and Crohn’s disease, it is not specific to either and thus does not aid in distinguishing between the two conditions.

 

Option C. Lymphoid aggregates in the mucosa: Lymphoid aggregates can be seen in both ulcerative colitis and Crohn’s disease, though they are more common in Crohn’s disease. However, this feature alone is not specific enough to differentiate between the two diseases.

 

Option D. Crypt abscesses: Crypt abscesses, formed by clusters of neutrophils within colonic crypts, are a feature of active inflammation in both ulcerative colitis and Crohn’s disease, and thus are not helpful in differentiating between them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The diffuse distribution of pseudopolyps is characteristic of ulcerative colitis, distinguishing it from Crohn’s disease, which tends to have a patchy, segmental involvement of the intestinal mucosa.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the Xray ?
During which phase of the cardiac cycle is the third heart sound (S3) most commonly associated?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rapid filling phase

 

  • The third heart sound (S3) is associated with the rapid filling phase of the cardiac cycle. 
  • This phase occurs early in diastole when blood flows rapidly from the atria into the ventricles due to the pressure difference. 
  • The sound arises due to vibrations in the ventricular walls caused by the sudden filling, especially in conditions where there is increased flow or reduced ventricular compliance.
  • Physiological S3: Common in children, young adults, and pregnant women due to high cardiac output.
  • Pathological S3: Found in heart failure, volume overload conditions (e.g., mitral regurgitation), and decreased ventricular compliance (e.g., dilated cardiomyopathy).
  • The timing of S3 after S2 during diastole is a hallmark of this heart sound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isovolumetric contraction phase: This phase occurs early in systole when the ventricles contract but no blood is ejected yet because all valves are closed. No heart sounds are typically produced during this phase.

 

Option C. Isovolumetric relaxation phase: This phase occurs early in diastole after the closure of the semilunar valves (S2) but before the opening of the atrioventricular valves. It does not involve rapid filling, so S3 is not produced during this phase.

 

Option D. Rapid ejection phase: This occurs during systole as blood is ejected from the ventricles into the great arteries. It is unrelated to the production of S3.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The third heart sound (S3) is linked to the rapid filling phase of diastole and is most often a sign of either physiological high-output states or pathological conditions like heart failure or ventricular dilation.

questions.text: Identify the type of drain:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Closed suction

 

  • The drain shown in the image is a closed suction drain, which is commonly used in surgical procedures to remove fluids from a wound or body cavity. 
  • This type of drain helps prevent infection by containing fluids within a closed system and applying gentle suction to aid in drainage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open suction: In an open suction drain, the collected fluid is drained into an open system, such as a gauze or container without any closed mechanism, which increases the risk of infection and is generally not preferred in modern surgical settings.

 

Option C. Closed continuous: This term can sometimes refer to closed systems that have continuous drainage but may not specifically use suction. Closed continuous drains maintain a sealed environment but may differ in application compared to closed suction.

 

Option D. Semi closed: Semi-closed systems are less commonly used and may allow partial exposure to the external environment, reducing the containment of fluids and increasing infection risks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Closed suction drains provide a safe and effective way to manage post-operative fluid accumulation and reduce infection risks by containing fluids in a closed environment while applying suction to promote drainage.

questions.text: Identify the hormone:

A 23-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain and a rapidly growing pelvic mass. Serum tumor markers show significantly elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels. An ovarian biopsy is performed, and the histopathological examination is shown below. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old man presents to the ER with sudden onset of left-sided facial weakness that developed overnight. He is unable to close his left eye, and the angle of his mouth droops. He denies any recent trauma, rash, or hearing loss. Physical examination reveals an inability to raise his left eyebrow and decreased tear production in the left eye. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oral corticosteroids

 

  • Corticosteroids, such as prednisone, are the mainstay of treatment for Bell's palsy and are most effective when started within 72 hours of symptom onset. 
  • They reduce inflammation and edema around the facial nerve, improving the chances of full recovery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antiviral therapy: Antiviral therapy (e.g., acyclovir or valacyclovir) may be used in combination with corticosteroids if there is a suspicion of viral involvement, such as herpes simplex virus. However, corticosteroids remain the primary initial treatment.

 

Option C. Antibiotic therapy: Antibiotics are not indicated for Bell's palsy, as it is not caused by bacterial infection. They are reserved for conditions like otitis media or bacterial meningitis.

 

Option D. Surgical decompression: Surgical decompression is rarely required and is only considered in cases with confirmed nerve compression due to trauma or tumors. It is not a first-line treatment for idiopathic Bell's palsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The initial treatment for Bell's palsy is oral corticosteroids, which should be initiated within 72 hours of symptom onset to reduce inflammation and maximize the chances of full recovery.

questions.text: According to European hernia society classification (EHS), hernia labelled as PL2 implies?

A group of researchers investigates why individuals who have undergone gastrectomy lose more weight than can be explained by dietary changes alone. They recruit several subjects who have had distal gastrectomy for benign gastric-outlet obstruction for a clinical study. Control subjects with matching baseline weight are also enrolled and are instructed to follow a diet similar to that of the postgastrectomy subjects during the study period. Plasma levels of several hormones are serially measured over 24 hours in both groups. Levels of one of the hormones are shown in the graph below. This profile most likely represents which of the following hormones?

choices.text: Accumulation of lead inhibiting RNA degradation
Iron deficiency leading to impaired hemoglobin synthesis
Excess alpha-globin chains precipitating in red blood cells
Decreased heme synthesis due to vitamin B6 deficiency

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with fatigue, abdominal pain, and difficulty concentrating. He works at a battery manufacturing plant. Laboratory investigations and peripheral blood smear shown below. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Accumulation of lead inhibiting RNA degradation

 

  • The presence of basophilic stippling along with microcytic hypochromic anemia in the context of occupational exposure to lead strongly suggests lead poisoning. Lead inhibits enzymes such as pyrimidine 5'-nucleotidase, which is responsible for degrading ribosomal RNA. The accumulation of RNA within red blood cells appears as basophilic stippling on a smear.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Iron deficiency leading to impaired hemoglobin synthesis: Incorrect. Iron deficiency anemia also causes microcytic hypochromic anemia but does not result in basophilic stippling.

 

Option C. Excess alpha-globin chains precipitating in red blood cells: Incorrect. This is seen in beta-thalassemia, which may present with microcytosis but is not associated with occupational lead exposure or basophilic stippling.

 

Option D. Decreased heme synthesis due to vitamin B6 deficiency: Incorrect. Vitamin B6 deficiency causes sideroblastic anemia, which may show ringed sideroblasts in the bone marrow, not basophilic stippling on a peripheral smear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Basophilic stippling is a classic finding in lead poisoning due to inhibited RNA degradation. Occupational exposure history and characteristic smear findings are crucial for diagnosis.

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman presented with progressive memory loss, confusion, and difficulty in performing daily activities. After her death, an autopsy was performed, and histopathological examination of the brain is shown in the image below. What are these inclusions called, and with which neurodegenerative condition are they most commonly associated?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hirano bodies, Alzheimer's disease

 

  • Hirano bodies are eosinophilic, rod-shaped inclusions typically found in the hippocampal neurons. 
  • They are composed of actin and other cytoskeletal proteins and are often associated with Alzheimer's disease. 
  • These inclusions are not specific to Alzheimer's but are seen more frequently in individuals with this condition, especially in advanced stages.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lewy bodies, Parkinson's disease: Lewy bodies are spherical eosinophilic inclusions found in the cytoplasm of neurons, typically associated with Parkinson's disease and Lewy body dementia. They consist of alpha-synuclein and are commonly found in the substantia nigra.

 

 

Option C. Negri bodies, Rabies: Negri bodies are eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions seen in the neurons of individuals infected with the rabies virus. They are typically found in the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum and are diagnostic for rabies infection.

 

 

Option D. Pick bodies, Pick's disease: Pick bodies are intracytoplasmic inclusions found in neurons affected by Pick's disease, a form of frontotemporal dementia. They are composed of tau protein and are found in specific regions of the brain associated with behaviour and language.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hirano bodies are eosinophilic, rod-shaped inclusions found in hippocampal neurons and are commonly associated with Alzheimer's disease.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man presents with difficulty recognizing his wife, friends, and acquaintances. Brain imaging reveals a lesion in the right anterior temporal lobe extending posteriorly and laterally, involving the middle fusiform gyrus and inferior temporal gyrus. Which of the visual field disturbances shown in the image is most likely to occur in this patient?

choices.text: Contraction of the base of tongue

questions.text: A 70-year old man comes to the OPD due to persistent aspiration. Two weeks ago, he had a stroke that impacted his speech, voice, and swallowing. Aspiration is ameliorated when the patient flexes his neck to put his chin to his chest during swallowing. This maneuver is most likely augmenting which of the following airway-protective mechanisms?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Superior displacement of the larynx

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presents with complaints of difficulty looking downward, especially when reading or descending stairs. Upon examination, you note that the patient has difficulty moving the eye downward and laterally. Which cranial nerve is most likely injured?

choices.text: Pain in both active and passive movements

questions.text: Non-articular bone pain is differentiated from articular bone pain by:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pain in only active movements

 

  • This is typical of non-articular bone pain. Non-articular pain usually comes from structures outside the joint itself, such as muscles, ligaments, tendons, or bone itself (e.g., bone stress, fractures, or conditions like periosteitis). 
  • This pain typically arises during active movements, when the affected structure is actively used or stretched. Passive movement doesn't aggravate this pain because the joint is not being moved directly or the involved soft tissue isn't under tension when it’s passively moved.
  • Non-articular pain is usually reproduced only with active movement, as it involves tissues outside the joint capsule, such as muscles and bones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pain in both active and passive movements:

 

  • This is more typical of articular pain, where the joint (articular structure) is involved. When both active (when the person moves the joint) and passive (when someone else moves the joint) movements cause pain, it indicates that the pain is coming from the joint itself, particularly the cartilage or the synovial membrane, which can be affected by conditions like arthritis.
  • Non-articular pain generally does not worsen with passive movement.

 

Option C. Crepitus:

 

  • Crepitus refers to a crackling or grating sound that is often heard when bones or joints move against each other. This is a sign of articular problems, especially if there is damage to the cartilage or the joint surface (like in osteoarthritis). It is commonly seen in joint-related pain, as the roughened surfaces of the bones rub against each other.

  • Crepitus is associated with articular conditions, not non-articular bone pain.

     

Option D. Swelling:

 

  • Swelling is more characteristic of articular pain, where inflammation in the joint (e.g., synovitis, bursitis) or an injury causes fluid buildup within the joint. Swelling is usually not seen in non-articular bone pain unless there is a traumatic injury or infection involving the surrounding soft tissue. Swelling is not a direct feature of non-articular bone pain, unless there's a secondary complication.

  • Non-articular pain typically does not involve joint swelling.

     

Educational Objective:

 

  • Non-articular bone pain is differentiated by pain only during active movements, whereas articular pain typically affects both active and passive movements, can involve crepitus, and may result in swelling.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents with pain and swelling in the thigh since last one month. X-ray is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ewing sarcoma

 

The X-ray shows periosteal reaction with characteristic "onion-skin" (lamellated) appearance along the diaphysis of a long bone, which is classic for Ewing sarcoma seen in adolescents. The clinical history of rapid progression with pain and swelling supports this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteoclastoma: Typically arises at the epiphysis of long bones and affects young adults.

 

Option C. Brodie abscess: Presents as a well-defined, lucent lesion with surrounding sclerosis, usually not with onion-skin periosteal reaction.

 

Option D. Osteosarcoma: Shows sunburst or Codman's triangle periosteal reaction, generally in the metaphyseal region.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male presents with progressive difficulty in walking, slurred speech, and uncoordinated movements over the past year. On examination, he has a tremor, dystonia, and signs of dysarthria. An ophthalmologic examination is still pending. MRI of the brain is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Wilson’s disease

 

  • The "Panda sign" on MRI refers to a characteristic hyperintensity in the midbrain, bilateral putamen, and caudate nuclei seen on T2-weighted imaging. 
  • This is a hallmark finding in Wilson’s disease, a rare autosomal recessive disorder of copper metabolism caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene.

 

Key clinical features of Wilson’s disease include:

 

  • Neurological symptoms: Tremors, dysarthria, dystonia, and ataxia.
  • Ophthalmologic findings: Kayser-Fleischer rings due to copper deposition in the Descemet's membrane of the cornea.
  • Hepatic involvement: May range from asymptomatic elevation of liver enzymes to fulminant liver failure.
  • MRI findings reflect copper deposition and neurotoxicity, leading to characteristic imaging patterns such as the Panda sign.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Huntington’s disease: Presents with chorea, behavioral changes, and cognitive decline. MRI shows caudate and putamen atrophy but does not produce the Panda sign.

 

Option C. Parkinson’s disease: Characterized by degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra, with imaging findings of hypointensity in the basal ganglia, not the Panda sign.

 

Option D. Multiple sclerosis: A demyelinating disease with white matter plaques visible on MRI, typically not involving the basal ganglia or producing the Panda sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recognize the Panda sign on MRI as a diagnostic clue for Wilson’s disease.
  • Understand the clinical presentation of Wilson’s disease, including neurological, hepatic, and ophthalmologic manifestations.
  • Differentiate the imaging findings of Wilson’s disease from other movement disorders and demyelinating conditions.

questions.text: Identify the instrument given in the image:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tonometer

 

  • The instrument shown in the image is a Perkins Tonometer. 
  • This handheld device is specifically designed for measuring intraocular pressure (IOP), which is crucial for the diagnosis and management of conditions like glaucoma. 
  • The Perkins Tonometer is particularly useful in settings where traditional, slit-lamp-mounted tonometers are impractical, such as in nursing homes or for bedridden patients, due to its portability and versatility in measuring IOP in various patient positions.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Ophthalmoscope: Incorrect. An ophthalmoscope is used to examine the interior structures of the eye, primarily the retina, not to measure intraocular pressure. 

 

 

Option C. Otoscope: Incorrect. An otoscope is utilized for examining the ear canal and eardrum, not the eye. 

 

 

Option D. Phoropter: Incorrect. A phoropter is used during eye exams to determine an individual's eyeglass or contact lens prescription, distinct from measuring intraocular pressure.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Tonometer is an essential tool in ophthalmology for measuring intraocular pressure, crucial for the diagnosis and management of glaucoma.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the OPD after developing fever and a sore throat. A rapid antigen detection test confirms the diagnosis of streptococcal throat infection. Her condition resolves with antibiotic therapy. Several weeks later, she is re-exposed to Streptococcus pyogenes. The bacteria penetrating beyond the surface epithelium are immediately coated with preformed IgG antibodies. Which of the following substances acts in the most similar manner to IgG antibodies to facilitate phagocytosis?

choices.text: Palmar cutaneous branch of median nerve

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents to the emergency department after a superficial self-inflicted cut across the front of her wrist over the flexor retinaculum. Which of the following structures is least likely to have been damaged in this superficial injury?

A 27-year-old patient is brought into the casualty with maxillofacial trauma following a road traffic accident (RTA). He is unconscious with a GCS of 7/15 and his SpO2 is dropping with absent breath sounds on right side. JVP is raised. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cricothyrodotomy

 

This patient has severe maxillofacial trauma, making conventional oral or nasal intubation impossible. With a GCS of 7, definitive airway protection is mandatory. Cricothyrotomy provides a rapid surgical airway when standard intubation is not feasible. It is lifesaving in emergency trauma airway management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bag and mask ventilation: Not adequate in maxillofacial trauma because airway obstruction is likely, and it does not secure a definitive airway in an unconscious patient with low GCS.

 

Option C. Needle thoracostomy: The patient does have features of tension pneumothorax (absent breath sounds, raised JVP, hypoxia), but the airway must be secured first. Oxygenation will not improve without a patent airway.

 

Option D. Nasotracheal intubation: Contraindicated in maxillofacial trauma as it can worsen airway compromise, cause bleeding, and risk intracranial passage if base of skull fracture exists.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents to the casualty with chest pain radiating to the back. He is diagnosed with a type A aortic dissection and undergoes emergent open repair. During the postoperative period, he develops thoracic back pain and an inability to move his bilateral lower extremities. Pinprick testing reveals bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation below the level of the xiphoid process. Injury to which of the following arteries most likely explains this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Artery of Adamkiewicz

 

  • The artery of Adamkiewicz, also known as the great anterior radiculomedullary artery, is the principal blood supply to the anterior spinal artery in the thoracolumbar region. 
  • It typically arises between T9 and T12 but can originate anywhere from T8 to L2. 
  • In aortic dissection or during surgical repair, disruption of blood flow to this artery can cause anterior spinal artery syndrome, which manifests as:
  • Motor deficits: Bilateral lower extremity paralysis due to corticospinal tract involvement.
  • Sensory deficits: Loss of pain and temperature sensation below the lesion due to spinothalamic tract involvement.
  • Preservation of dorsal columns: Fine touch, vibration, and proprioception remain intact as they are supplied by the posterior spinal arteries.
  • The artery of Adamkiewicz is especially vulnerable during thoracic aortic procedures, leading to spinal cord ischemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anterior thoracic epidural artery: This artery supplies the epidural space and vertebral bodies and is not directly responsible for spinal cord perfusion.

 

Option C. Posterior spinal arteries: These supply the dorsal columns responsible for proprioception and fine touch, which remain intact in this case.

 

Option D. Middle meningeal artery: This artery supplies the dura mater and calvaria, not the spinal cord, and is unrelated to this presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understand the role of the artery of Adamkiewicz in supplying the thoracolumbar region of the spinal cord.
  • Recognize anterior spinal artery syndrome as a complication of aortic dissection and its repair.
  • Differentiate between vascular territories of the spinal cord and their clinical implications.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with progressive hearing loss in the right ear and occasional imbalance over the past year. On examination, there is reduced hearing on the right side but no other focal neurological deficits. MRI of the brain is shown below. Which of the following genetic mutations is most likely associated with this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gene mutation on chromosome 22

 

  • This patient’s presentation of bilateral vestibular schwannomas (acoustic neuromas) is diagnostic of neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF-2). NF-2 is caused by a mutation in the NF2 gene on chromosome 22, which encodes the tumor suppressor protein merlin. This condition is characterized by bilateral vestibular schwannomas, leading to hearing loss, tinnitus, and balance problems.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Gene mutation on chromosome 17: Incorrect. Mutations on chromosome 17 are associated with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF-1), which is characterized by cutaneous neurofibromas, café-au-lait spots, and Lisch nodules, not bilateral vestibular schwannomas.

 

Option C. RET proto-oncogene mutation: Incorrect. RET mutations are linked to multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2), characterized by medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and hyperparathyroidism, not acoustic neuromas.

 

Option D. TP53 gene mutation: Incorrect. TP53 mutations are associated with Li-Fraumeni syndrome, which predisposes to various malignancies, such as sarcomas and breast cancer, but not vestibular schwannomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bilateral vestibular schwannomas are a hallmark of neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF-2), which is caused by mutations in the NF2 gene on chromosome 22. Early recognition is crucial for management and preventing complications such as complete hearing loss.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with a severe, sudden-onset, throbbing headache and double vision for the past 30 minutes. She has a history of migraine and reports frequent headaches. She has not had her period for several months. On examination, her blood pressure is 95/61 mm Hg, and visual field testing reveals decreased visual acuity and loss of peripheral vision in both eyes. MRI of brain is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pituitary apoplexy

 

  • Pituitary apoplexy is an acute medical emergency caused by hemorrhage or infarction of the pituitary gland, often in the setting of a pre-existing pituitary adenoma. This condition explains the patient's presentation, including:
  • Sudden severe headache: Due to acute hemorrhage or ischemia in the pituitary.
  • Double vision and visual field defects: Result from compression of the optic chiasm or nearby cranial nerves.
  • Amenorrhea: Indicates hormonal dysfunction caused by impaired pituitary function.
  • Hypotension: Due to acute adrenal insufficiency caused by secondary hypopituitarism.
  • Immediate treatment with glucocorticoids is critical to manage adrenal insufficiency, along with surgical decompression if needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transient ischemic attack: TIAs typically present with transient neurological deficits (e.g., unilateral weakness, speech changes) and do not cause severe headache, hormonal dysfunction, or bilateral visual field loss.

 

Option C. Sheehan syndrome: Sheehan syndrome involves postpartum pituitary infarction due to obstetric hemorrhage. This patient’s presentation is unrelated to pregnancy or delivery.

 

Option D. Migraine with aura: Migraine may cause visual disturbances (e.g., scotomas) but does not lead to bilateral visual field loss, hypotension, or hormonal dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recognize the clinical features of pituitary apoplexy, including headache, visual disturbances, and hormonal dysfunction.
  • Understand the importance of rapid glucocorticoid replacement to manage adrenal insufficiency in this condition.
  • Differentiate pituitary apoplexy from other causes of headache and visual disturbances.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with acute visual loss. He has been admitted since last one week for severe acute pancreatitis. Given the fundoscopic appearance, which posterior segment pathology is the most likely diagnosis?
What is the likely diagnosis of the image shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Coxa vara

 

COXA VARA:

 

  • Coxa vara is a term used to describe a reduced angle between the neck and shaft of the femur. 
  • It may be congenital/acquired (growth anomaly at upper femoral epiphysis) or acquired (secondary to various other pathologies).
  • The normal femoral neck shaft angle is 160° at birth, decreasing to 135 degrees in adult life. An angle of <120 degrees is called coxa vara. 

 

 

INFANTILE COXA VARA

 

  • This is coxa vara resulting from some unknown growth anomaly at the upper femoral epiphysis. 
  • It is noticed as a painless limp in a child who has just started walking. 
  • In severe cases, shortening of the leg may be obvious. 
  • On examination, abduction and internal rotation of the hip are limited and the leg is short. 
  • X-rays will show a reduction in neck-shaft angle.
  • The epiphyseal plate may be too vertical. 
  • There may be a separate triangle of bone in the inferior portion of the metaphysis, called Fairbank’s triangle. 

 

 

  • Treatment: Subtrochanteric corrective osteotomy.

     

Other Options:

 

Option A. Coxa magna: Coxa magna is the asymmetrical, circumferential enlargement and deformation of the femoral head and neck. It is seen in Legg-Calve-Perthes disease, transient synovitis of the hip, developmental dysplasia of the hip, trauma, septic arthritis/osteomyelitis, juvenile rheumatoid arthritis, chronic slipped capital femoral epiphysis. 

 

 

Option B. Coxa valga: Coxa valga is a deformity of the hip where there is an increased angle between the femoral neck and femoral shaft. It is often associated with shallow  and femoral head subluxation. Bilateral coxa valga can be seen in cerebral palsy, turner syndrome. Unilateral occurs due to trauma causing growth plate arrest. Angle more than 140° is considered as coxa valga. 

 

 

Option D. Coxa Saltans: It is a condition characterized by a snapping sensation in the hip that comprises of 3 entities: external snapping hip (caused by iliotibial tract sliding over greater trochanter), internal snapping hip (caused by iliopsoas tendon sliding over femoral head, iliopectineal ridge, lesser trochanter, and iliopsoas bursa), and intra-articular snapping hip (caused by loose body in hip/labral tears). It is common in athletes and dancers in their teens or twenties. X-ray usually appears normal. MRI may show inflamed bursa. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image in the question shows coxa vara i.e., reduced angle between the neck and shaft of the femur.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with chronic pain that he has been managing by applying pressure to the painful area, which temporarily relieves his discomfort. Which neural site is primarily involved in this pain-relief mechanism?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Periaqueductal gray

 

  • The periaqueductal gray, located in the midbrain, is a critical center in the brain’s pain modulation pathway. 
  • When pressure is applied to a painful area, it can activate endogenous analgesic systems, including the PAG, which releases endorphins and enkephalins that inhibit pain perception. 
  • The PAG modulates pain signals through descending inhibitory pathways, resulting in temporary pain relief.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial longitudinal fasciculus: This structure coordinates eye movements and head movements but does not play a role in pain modulation.

 

Option B. Medial lemniscus: The medial lemniscus carries sensory information (fine touch, proprioception) from the body to the brain but is not involved in pain inhibition.

 

Option C. Corticospinal tract: This tract transmits motor commands from the brain to the spinal cord, controlling voluntary muscle movements but is unrelated to pain modulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The periaqueductal gray (PAG) in the midbrain is involved in pain modulation by activating descending inhibitory pathways that can relieve pain when pressure is applied to painful areas.

questions.text:
Match each contraceptive to its correct type based on its function and delivery mechanism.

 

Contraceptives and Types:

 

A. Vaginal Sponge

B. Norplant

C. NET–EN

D. Grafenberg’s Ring

 

Types of Contraceptive: 

 

I. Subdermal implant
II. Barrier Method
III. Intrauterine device (IUD)
IV. Depot formulation
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A - II, B - I, C - IV, D – III

 

  • A - II (Vaginal Sponge): The Vaginal Sponge is a barrier method of contraception. It is placed inside the vagina to block sperm from entering the uterus.
  • B - I (Norplant): Norplant is a subdermal implant. It consists of small rods inserted under the skin, which release hormones over a prolonged period to prevent pregnancy.
  • C - IV (NET–EN): NET–EN, or Norethisterone Enantate, is a depot formulation. It is an injectable contraceptive that provides long-term hormonal prevention of pregnancy.
  • D – III (Grafenberg’s Ring): Grafenberg’s Ring is considered an early type of intrauterine device (IUD). It is placed inside the uterus to prevent sperm from fertilizing an egg.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A. Vaginal Sponge → II. Barrier Method

B. Norplant → I. Subdermal implant

C. NET–EN → IV. Depot formulation

D. Grafenberg’s Ring → III. Intrauterine device (IUD)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with lethargy, confusion, a fainting episode 2 hours ago, and weight gain over the past 2 months. His father had a history of recurrent stomach ulcers. Laboratory studies reveal a glucose concentration of 45 mg/dL and an increased C-peptide concentration. CT scan of the abdomen is shown below. The hormone most likely causing this patient’s symptoms is originally synthesized in which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rough endoplasmic reticulum

 

  • The patient likely has an insulinoma, a tumor of the pancreatic beta cells that causes excessive insulin secretion. Insulin is a peptide hormone initially synthesized as preproinsulin in the rough endoplasmic reticulum of pancreatic beta cells. It is then processed into proinsulin and subsequently cleaved into insulin and C-peptide, which are stored in secretory granules and co-released.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Mitochondria: Incorrect. Mitochondria are involved in energy production and some aspects of steroid hormone synthesis but are not involved in the synthesis of peptide hormones like insulin.

 

Option B. Free ribosomes: Incorrect. Free ribosomes synthesize proteins that function within the cytosol. Secretory proteins, like insulin, are synthesized by ribosomes bound to the rough endoplasmic reticulum.

 

Option C. Secretory granules: Incorrect. Secretory granules are responsible for storing and releasing insulin and C-peptide but are not the site of initial synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Peptide hormones like insulin are synthesized in the rough endoplasmic reticulum, processed in the Golgi apparatus, and stored in secretory granules before being released into circulation. Elevated insulin and C-peptide levels suggest endogenous insulin production, commonly seen in insulinoma.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman faints after standing up quickly. She reports weight loss, cravings for potato chips, and generalized weakness. On examination, her blood pressure is 94/60 mm Hg, and areas of hyperpigmentation are noted on the skin and gums. Serum studies reveal a sodium level of 132 mEq/L, potassium of 5.5 mEq/L, chloride of 106 mEq/L, and bicarbonate of 19 mEq/L. Which of the following is most likely elevated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ACTH

 

  • This patient's presentation is suggestive of Addison's disease (primary adrenal insufficiency), which results from insufficient production of cortisol and aldosterone by the adrenal glands. 
  • The hyperpigmentation of the skin and gums is due to elevated ACTH levels, which is a compensatory response to low cortisol. 
  • ACTH stimulates melanocytes, causing the characteristic hyperpigmentation. 
  • The electrolyte abnormalities, such as hyponatremia and hyperkalemia, also support this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aldosterone: In primary adrenal insufficiency, aldosterone production is typically low, which leads to sodium wasting, hyperkalemia, and hypotension, not elevated levels of aldosterone.

 

Option C. Androgens: In Addison's disease, the adrenal glands produce insufficient amounts of androgens, so these are usually low, not elevated.

 

Option D. Insulin: There is no indication of insulin dysregulation in this patient’s presentation, and the elevated potassium levels are not related to insulin production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In Addison's disease, ACTH levels are elevated due to decreased cortisol production, which stimulates melanocytes and causes the characteristic hyperpigmentation.

questions.text: Which of the following represents the correct order of events involved in lactation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mammogenesis → Lactogenesis → Galactokinesis → Galactopoiesis

 

The process of lactation occurs in a precise order, which can be divided into the following stages:

 

  1. Mammogenesis: The development of the mammary gland, which begins during puberty and continues throughout pregnancy, involves the preparation of the breast tissue for milk production. Hormones such as estrogen, progesterone, and prolactin play key roles in this stage.
  2. Lactogenesis: The initiation of milk production, which occurs in two phases. Lactogenesis I begins in mid-pregnancy, while Lactogenesis II starts after delivery with the onset of copious milk secretion triggered by the withdrawal of progesterone and increased prolactin levels.
  3. Galactokinesis: The ejection of milk from the mammary gland to the infant, facilitated by oxytocin, which triggers contraction of myoepithelial cells surrounding the alveoli.
  4. Galactopoiesis: The maintenance of milk production, which is driven by continued suckling and the subsequent release of prolactin and oxytocin. Feedback inhibition mechanisms regulate the volume of milk produced.
  • The correct sequence is Mammogenesis → Lactogenesis → Galactokinesis → Galactopoiesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The process of lactation follows the correct sequence of Mammogenesis → Lactogenesis → Galactokinesis → Galactopoiesis, encompassing mammary gland development, milk production, milk ejection, and the maintenance of milk supply postpartum.
  • This process is regulated by hormonal changes during pregnancy and the puerperium.

A 55-year-old woman presents with new-onset diabetes, weight loss, and a painful, erythematous rash on her face, hands, and buttocks. She has a history of recurrent episodes of confusion and weakness, especially after fasting. On examination, the patient has a rash (as shown below), and her blood glucose level is 300 mg/dL. Laboratory studies are pending. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glucagonoma

 

  • This patient’s presentation of new-onset diabetes, weight loss, confusion and weakness after fasting, and a characteristic erythematous, painful rash is highly suggestive of glucagonoma. 
  • The rash, necrolytic migratory erythema (NME), is a hallmark of glucagonoma, a rare pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor that secretes glucagon. 
  • This leads to hyperglycemia, weight loss, and skin changes. 
  • The elevated blood glucose level further supports this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cushing’s syndrome: Cushing’s syndrome presents with features like central obesity, moon face, and purple striae, and it does not typically cause necrolytic migratory erythema.

 

Option C. Hyperthyroidism: Hyperthyroidism can cause weight loss and diabetes but does not cause necrolytic migratory erythema.

 

Option D. Acromegaly: Acromegaly is characterized by excess growth hormone and features such as enlarged hands, feet, and facial changes, but it does not present with necrolytic migratory erythema or diabetes associated with the rash seen in glucagonoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Necrolytic migratory erythema (NME) is a distinctive skin rash associated with glucagonoma, a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor. 
  • It is important to recognize this rash, as it is often accompanied by hyperglycemia, weight loss, and other systemic symptoms.

questions.text: A patient presented with painless decrease in vision and metamorphopsia. Fundus examination revealed the lesion shown in the image. What is the expected finding on angiography?

In the management of a hospital-acquired infection, a patient's bacterial culture grows Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). Which gene is primarily responsible for conferring resistance to semisynthetic penicillins in MRSA?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) mecA

 

  • Methicillin resistance in Staphylococcus aureus is primarily mediated by the chromosomally encoded mecA gene. 
  • This gene alters the penicillin-binding protein (PBP) on the S. aureus cell membrane to a specific form known as PBP-2a.
  • Normally, PBPs are crucial for bacterial cell wall synthesis, as they catalyze the final stages of this process. 
  • β-lactam antibiotics typically exert their effect by binding to these proteins, thereby inhibiting cell wall synthesis and leading to bacterial cell death. 
  • However, PBP-2a, produced as a result of the mecA gene, has significantly reduced affinity for β-lactam antibiotics compared to the native PBPs. 
  • This alteration allows MRSA strains to continue cell wall synthesis in the presence of β-lactam antibiotics, thereby conferring broad resistance. 
  • While the mecC gene, which codes for PBP-2c, has also been identified in association with MRSA, the mecA gene is the predominant mechanism responsible for resistance in these strains and is therefore the most relevant in clinical settings.

 

Other Options:


Option B. mecB: Incorrect. There is no known mecB gene associated with β-lactam resistance in MRSA.


Option C. mecD: Incorrect. This gene is not recognized as a contributor to methicillin resistance in MRSA strains.


Option D. mecC: Incorrect. Although mecC, which encodes PBP-2c, contributes to methicillin resistance, mecA is more prevalent and clinically significant in most MRSA infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The role of the mecA gene in conferring methicillin resistance in MRSA, emphasizing its impact on altering the penicillin-binding protein to PBP-2a, which is less susceptible to β-lactam antibiotics, thus enabling the persistence of cell wall synthesis despite antibiotic presence.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the outpatient department with complaints of severe headache, sweating, and palpitations over the past couple of weeks. His blood pressure is 180/100 mmHg. The patient mentions a family history of a tumor associated with hypertension. Laboratory tests show elevated urinary and plasma catecholamines and metanephrines. Based on these findings, which of the following genes is most likely mutated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) RET

 

  • This patient presents with symptoms suggestive of pheochromocytoma, a catecholamine-secreting tumor commonly found in the adrenal medulla. 
  • The elevated levels of urinary and plasma catecholamines and metanephrines are consistent with this diagnosis. 
  • Pheochromocytomas are often associated with inherited syndromes, and the RET gene mutation is commonly linked to multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2), which predisposes individuals to pheochromocytoma, medullary thyroid cancer, and hyperparathyroidism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BRAF: BRAF mutations are typically associated with melanoma, papillary thyroid carcinoma, and other malignancies, but they are not associated with pheochromocytomas.

 

Option B. MEN1: MEN1 mutations are linked to multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1, which predisposes to tumors of the parathyroids, pancreas, and pituitary gland, but not typically pheochromocytomas.

 

Option D. RAS: RAS mutations are implicated in various cancers, including pancreatic and colon cancers, but they are not typically associated with pheochromocytoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The RET gene mutation is most commonly associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2), which includes pheochromocytoma as a key feature. 
  • Identifying this mutation helps in the diagnosis of hereditary forms of pheochromocytoma and guides further management and genetic counseling.
