questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the office due to double vision. The patient first experienced difficulty focusing her eyes while at work yesterday. Shining light into the patient's right eye causes constriction of her right pupil, but not the left pupil. Shining light into her left eye causes constriction of only her right pupil. questions.text: When is the best time to perform Breast self-examination (BSE) in menstruating women?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 week after menstruation

 

  • The best time to perform breast self-examination (BSE) is 1 week after menstruation. 
  • At this point in the menstrual cycle, hormone levels (specifically estrogen and progesterone) are at their lowest, resulting in less breast engorgement or tenderness. 
  • This makes it easier to detect any abnormalities such as lumps, thickening, or changes in the breast tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1 week before menstruation: This is not ideal because hormonal changes during the premenstrual phase can cause breast swelling and tenderness, making the examination less accurate.

 

Option C. During ovulation: During ovulation, estrogen levels rise, which can cause breast tissue to feel denser or tender, reducing the effectiveness of BSE.

 

Option D. 2-3 days post-ovulation: Hormonal changes during this time can still affect the breast tissue, making it a less ideal time for BSE compared to 1 week after menstruation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The optimal time for performing breast self-examination (BSE) is 1 week after menstruation, when hormonal influences on breast tissue are minimal, allowing for a more accurate assessment.

A 60-year-old woman presents to your clinic with symptoms of generalized weakness, fatigue, and diarrhea for the past few months. She also reports a sensation of "pins and needles" in her feet. She has a history of hypothyroidism. Physical examination reveals decreased sensation to pinprick in her toes bilaterally and a positive Romberg sign. Peripheral smear image is shown below. This patient is most likely deficient in a substance produced by which of the following types of cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Parietal cells

 

  • This patient presents with symptoms consistent with vitamin B12 deficiency, which can lead to neurological symptoms such as peripheral neuropathy ("pins and needles") and a positive Romberg sign. 
  • Parietal cells in the stomach produce intrinsic factor, which is necessary for the absorption of vitamin B12 in the ileum. 
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency is often associated with conditions such as pernicious anemia, which involves autoimmune destruction of parietal cells, leading to impaired intrinsic factor production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chief cells: Chief cells in the stomach secrete pepsinogen, which is involved in protein digestion, but they are not involved in the production of intrinsic factor or vitamin B12 absorption.

 

Option B. G cells: G cells in the stomach produce gastrin, which stimulates the secretion of gastric acid, but they do not produce intrinsic factor.

 

Option D. Mucous cells: Mucous cells secrete mucus that protects the stomach lining from acid, but they are not involved in vitamin B12 absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vitamin B12 deficiency is often caused by impaired intrinsic factor production due to damage to the parietal cells in the stomach, leading to symptoms such as peripheral neuropathy and a positive Romberg sign. 
  • Recognizing the source of intrinsic factor production is key in understanding the pathophysiology of this deficiency.

questions.text: A 32-year-old HIV-positive male presents to the emergency department with progressive shortness of breath, fever, and a dry cough over the past week. He has not been taking antiretroviral therapy or prophylactic medications. On examination, his oxygen saturation is 89% on room air, and he has bilateral crackles on auscultation. Laboratory investigations reveal a CD4 count of 180 cells/µL. Chest X-ray shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX)

 

  • The patient’s clinical presentation, including progressive dyspnea, fever, dry cough, a low CD4 count, and bilateral interstitial infiltrates on chest X-ray, is highly suggestive of Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP). Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is the first-line treatment for PCP and should be initiated promptly. In severe cases, adjunctive corticosteroids may be considered to reduce inflammation and improve oxygenation.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Azithromycin: Incorrect. Azithromycin is used for prophylaxis and treatment of atypical infections such as Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) but is not effective against PCP.

 

Option C. Fluconazole: Incorrect. Fluconazole is an antifungal used for candidiasis or cryptococcal meningitis, but it is not effective against Pneumocystis jirovecii.

 

Option D. Doxycycline: Incorrect. Doxycycline is used for bacterial infections like atypical pneumonia (e.g., Chlamydia or Mycoplasma), but it has no activity against PCP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia is a common opportunistic infection in HIV-positive patients with CD4 counts <200 cells/µL. Prompt treatment with TMP-SMX and supportive care, including oxygen and corticosteroids if indicated, is essential for managing this life-threatening condition. Prophylaxis with TMP-SMX should be initiated in patients with low CD4 counts to prevent PCP.

A deceased individual is found after several days, and the forensic team is evaluating the progression of putrefaction in various organs to estimate the time since death. Among the following options, which organ is expected to undergo putrefaction first?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Brain

 

  • Among the given options, the brain is the first organ to undergo putrefaction. 
  • The process of putrefaction involves the decomposition of body tissues and follows a specific order from early to late stages.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heart: The heart putrefies after the brain but before the kidneys.

 

Option C. Kidney: The kidneys putrefy after the heart.

 

Option D. Prostate: The prostate putrefies very late in the process, even after the kidneys.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The order of organ putrefaction (early to late) is as follows:

 

  1. Larynx and trachea
  2. Liver and lungs
  3. Brain
  4. Heart
  5. Kidney 
  6. Prostate and Non Gravid uterus
  7. Skin, muscle, tendons
  8. Bones and teeth

 

Prostate and Non gravid uterus are organs which putrefy very late. The gravid uterus putrefies earlier.

 

Mnemonic: LBHK 

 

L for larynx, liver, lungs, B for brain H for Heart, K for Kidney

questions.text: Which histological variety of breast carcinoma has the best prognosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tubular carcinoma

 

  • Tubular carcinoma is a well-differentiated form of breast carcinoma and is associated with the best prognosis among the various histological subtypes of invasive breast cancer.
  • This subtype is characterized by small, uniform tubular structures and is typically slow-growing with a low risk of lymph node involvement and distant metastasis. 
  • Due to its favorable features, tubular carcinoma has an excellent overall survival rate and a low recurrence rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medullary carcinoma: Medullary carcinoma is a relatively rare and distinct subtype of breast cancer. It is characterized by high-grade tumor cells and a prominent lymphocytic infiltrate. Although it tends to have a relatively favorable prognosis compared to other high-grade carcinomas, it is not as good as tubular carcinoma in terms of overall survival.

 

Option B. Colloid (Mucinous) carcinoma: Colloid carcinoma, or mucinous carcinoma, is also associated with a favorable prognosis, as it is typically slow-growing and has low metastatic potential. However, tubular carcinoma has a better prognosis in terms of survival and recurrence rates compared to colloid carcinoma.

 

Option C. Lobular carcinoma: Invasive lobular carcinoma (ILC) is a subtype that tends to have a diffuse growth pattern and a higher likelihood of bilateral disease. It may also present with more difficulty in detection on imaging. While lobular carcinoma can be low-grade and well-differentiated, it generally has a less favorable prognosis compared to tubular carcinoma, with a higher risk of recurrence and distant metastasis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Tubular carcinoma of the breast is associated with the best prognosis among the invasive breast cancer subtypes.
  • It is well-differentiated, slow-growing, and has a low risk of metastasis. Early diagnosis and appropriate management are crucial in optimizing outcomes for patients with this type of breast carcinoma.
  • Other subtypes, such as medullary, colloid, and lobular carcinoma, have more variable prognoses and generally worse outcomes than tubular carcinoma.

questions.text: A 69-year-old woman presents with complaints of fatigue, abdominal discomfort, and weight loss. On examination, splenomegaly is noted. Her laboratory results show hemoglobin of 9.4 g/dL, leukocyte count of 58,000/mm³, segmented neutrophils 54%, bands 8%, lymphocytes 7%, blasts 5%, and platelet count of 850,000/mm³. A bone marrow biopsy reveals hyperplastic myelopoiesis with granulocytosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cytogenetic studies

 

  • This patient presents with features suggestive of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML), a myeloproliferative disorder characterized by leukocytosis, splenomegaly, and the presence of blasts in peripheral blood. 
  • Cytogenetic studies, including the detection of the Philadelphia chromosome (BCR-ABL gene fusion), are critical for confirming the diagnosis of CML. 
  • Identifying this chromosomal abnormality is crucial for guiding treatment decisions, such as the use of tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g., imatinib).

 

Other Options:


Option A. Cytarabine and daunorubicin therapy: This combination is used in the treatment of acute myelogenous leukemia (AML), not CML. CML is typically treated with tyrosine kinase inhibitors, not chemotherapy.

 

Option B. Serum protein electrophoresis: This test is used to diagnose plasma cell disorders, such as multiple myeloma, and is not relevant for CML.

 

Option D. Flow cytometry: While flow cytometry is useful in immunophenotyping leukemias and lymphomas, cytogenetic studies are more definitive for diagnosing CML, particularly for detecting the Philadelphia chromosome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the evaluation of suspected chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML), cytogenetic studies to identify the Philadelphia chromosome (BCR-ABL gene fusion) are crucial for diagnosis and treatment planning, including the use of tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

A 38-year-old man came with complaints of reduced vividness of colors. On examination, he was found to have altered depth perception for moving objects. This phenomenon is due to which of the following condition seen in this patient?

A 45-year-old man presents with progressive personality changes, apathy, and language difficulties. Family history reveals a similar disorder in his father. Genetic testing shows the presence of a hexanucleotide repeat expansion. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Frontotemporal Dementia

 

  • Frontotemporal dementia (FTD) is associated with a hexanucleotide repeat expansion (GGGGCC) in the C9orf72 gene, which is the most common genetic cause of FTD and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). 
  • The expansion leads to both loss of function of the gene and toxic gain of function of RNA products, causing neuronal degeneration. 
  • Clinically, FTD is characterized by behavioral and language changes, with a relatively early onset (before age 65).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Huntington Chorea: Huntington disease is caused by a trinucleotide repeat expansion (CAG) in the HTT gene, not a hexanucleotide repeat. It presents with chorea, psychiatric symptoms, and cognitive decline but is unrelated to the C9orf72 mutation.

 

Option B. Fragile X Syndrome: Fragile X syndrome is caused by a CGG trinucleotide repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene. It is a common cause of intellectual disability and is not associated with FTD or hexanucleotide repeat expansions.

 

Option C. Spinocerebellar Ataxia: Spinocerebellar ataxias are a group of neurodegenerative disorders caused by trinucleotide repeat expansions, often CAG. They present with progressive ataxia and other motor symptoms and are unrelated to hexanucleotide repeats.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Frontotemporal dementia is associated with a hexanucleotide repeat expansion in the C9orf72 gene, leading to progressive behavioral and language changes and sometimes overlapping with ALS features.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at approximately 8 weeks of gestation presents for her first prenatal visit. On physical examination, the physician notes increased pulsations in the lateral fornices upon bimanual examination. Which of the following signs is being described?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Osiander sign

 

  • Osiander sign refers to the increased pulsation of the uterine arteries that can be palpated in the lateral fornices during early pregnancy. 
  • This sign is one of the early clinical indications of pregnancy and is generally noted around 8 weeks of gestation. 
  • The increased blood flow in the uterine vessels during pregnancy causes these pulsations, which are more pronounced in the lateral fornices.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chadwick sign: Chadwick sign is a bluish discoloration of the cervix, vagina, and labia caused by increased blood flow to these areas, usually visible around 6 to 8 weeks of pregnancy. It is not associated with pulsations in the lateral fornices, making it distinct from Osiander sign.

 

Option B. Goodell sign: Goodell sign refers to the softening of the cervix in early pregnancy due to increased vascularization. Although it is an early sign of pregnancy, it does not involve the palpation of pulsations in the lateral fornices.

 

Option C. Piskacek sign: Piskacek sign is characterized by an asymmetric enlargement of the uterus due to implantation in one of the uterine cornua, typically observed during early pregnancy. It is unrelated to the pulsations felt in the lateral fornices and is instead associated with uterine shape.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Osiander sign is identified by increased pulsations felt through the lateral fornices, which is an early clinical indication of pregnancy.

questions.text: Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocyte to the plasma by binding to?

Sequentially arrange the steps involved in excitation-contraction coupling of smooth muscle cells.

 

  1. ﻿﻿﻿Myosin phosphorylation
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Increased influx of Ca2+ into the cell
  3. ﻿﻿﻿Activation of calmodulin-dependent myosin light chain kinase
  4. ﻿﻿﻿Binding of myosin to actin
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2-3-1-4

 

Sequence of events in smooth muscle excitation–contraction coupling:

 

2. Activation of calmodulin-dependent myosin light chain kinase (MLCK) – Ca²⁺ binds to calmodulin, forming a complex that activates MLCK.

3. Myosin phosphorylation – MLCK phosphorylates the myosin light chain, enabling cross-bridge formation.

1. Increased influx of Ca²⁺ into the cell – via voltage-gated, ligand-gated, or stretch-activated Ca²⁺ channels.

4. Binding of myosin to actin – phosphorylated myosin interacts with actin, leading to contraction.

 

Other Options:


Option A. 2-1-3-4: Wrong,phosphorylation cannot occur before MLCK activation.


Option B. 2-1-4-3: Wrong, actin binding occurs only after phosphorylation.
 

Option C. 3-2-1-4: Wrong, Ca²⁺ influx must occur before MLCK activation.

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement about CSF rhinorrhoea?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Leak of CSF occurs through a defect in the petrous apex

 

  • The leak of CSF does not typically occur through the petrous apex in cases of CSF rhinorrhoea. 
  • Instead, it usually occurs through a defect in the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone. 
  • A defect in the petrous apex is more commonly associated with CSF otorrhoea rather than CSF rhinorrhoea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reservoir sign is seen: The reservoir sign is positive in CSF rhinorrhoea. When the patient moves from a supine to a sitting position, fluid that collected in the sinuses, particularly the sphenoid sinus, is released, causing a gush of CSF from the nose.

 

Option B. Double Target Sign is seen (Halo Sign): The double target sign, also called the halo sign, is indicative of CSF leakage. When CSF mixed with blood is placed on an absorbent surface like gauze, it creates a central red spot (due to blood) with a clearer halo around it (due to CSF). This sign is typically seen in patients with trauma causing a CSF leak.

 

Option D. The watery Discharge Cannot be Sniffed Back: In CSF rhinorrhoea, the watery discharge cannot be sniffed back, unlike mucous secretions. This is due to the low viscosity of the CSF fluid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • CSF rhinorrhoea typically occurs due to a defect in the cribriform plate and can present with clear watery nasal discharge that cannot be sniffed back. 
  • Tests such as the reservoir sign and double ring (halo) sign can help in diagnosing a CSF leak.

A 42-year-old female presents with a 6-month history of joint pain, swelling, and stiffness, particularly involving her wrists, metacarpophalangeal, and proximal interphalangeal joints. She reports that the stiffness is worse in the morning and lasts for more than an hour. She also notes fatigue and difficulty performing daily activities. Laboratory testing reveals a positive rheumatoid factor (RF) and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies. Genetic testing identifies an HLA association. Which of the following HLA types is most strongly associated with this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HLA-DR4

 

  • The patient's clinical presentation, including symmetrical joint involvement, prolonged morning stiffness, and positive serologic markers (RF and anti-CCP), is characteristic of rheumatoid arthritis (RA). HLA-DR4 is the most strongly associated HLA type with RA, contributing to the autoimmune pathogenesis of the disease by influencing immune responses against citrullinated proteins.

 

Other Options:


Option A. HLA-B27: Incorrect. HLA-B27 is associated with seronegative spondyloarthropathies, such as ankylosing spondylitis and reactive arthritis, not RA.

 

Option C. HLA-Cw6: Incorrect. HLA-Cw6 is associated with psoriasis and psoriatic arthritis, not RA.

 

Option D. HLA-DR3: Incorrect. HLA-DR3 is associated with autoimmune diseases like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and type 1 diabetes mellitus, not RA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rheumatoid arthritis is closely linked to HLA-DR4, which is commonly present in patients with this disease. Understanding this genetic association aids in recognizing the autoimmune nature of RA and its predisposition in certain individuals.

A 35-year-old woman presents with recurrent episodes of flank pain and hematuria. She denies fever or weight loss. Her past medical history includes recurrent urinary tract infections. Urinalysis reveals microscopic hematuria and calcium phosphate crystals. An intravenous pyelogram (IVP) is performed, and the image shown demonstrates the characteristic findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Medullary sponge kidney

 

  • Medullary sponge kidney (MSK) is a congenital condition characterized by cystic dilatation of the collecting ducts within the renal medulla. 
  • The IVP image demonstrates a "paintbrush-like" appearance or "Swiss cheese" pattern, which is a hallmark of medullary sponge kidney.

 

Key Features of MSK:

 

  1. Recurrent flank pain: Due to nephrocalcinosis or urinary obstruction.
  2. Hematuria: Frequently microscopic and linked to nephrolithiasis.
  3. Recurrent urinary tract infections: Often caused by stasis of urine in the dilated collecting ducts.
  4. Imaging findings: IVP typically shows contrast-filled ectatic collecting ducts, giving the characteristic appearance seen in the provided image.

 

This condition is usually benign but may require management of recurrent infections, kidney stones, or metabolic abnormalities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD): Patients typically present with bilateral kidney enlargement, multiple cysts, and may have associated systemic findings like hypertension or hepatic cysts. Imaging shows large, well-defined cysts rather than the paintbrush-like appearance of MSK.

 

Option C. Chronic pyelonephritis: Characterized by scarring of the renal parenchyma, calyceal deformities, and thinning of the cortex on imaging. It does not exhibit the cystic changes or tubular dilations seen in MSK.

 

Option D. Renal cell carcinoma: Presents with solid masses or complex cystic lesions on imaging, often with systemic signs such as weight loss or paraneoplastic syndromes. IVP findings do not resemble the pattern of collecting duct dilatation seen in MSK.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Medullary sponge kidney is a congenital condition characterized by cystic dilatation of the renal medullary collecting ducts, often seen on imaging as a paintbrush-like appearance or Swiss cheese pattern on IVP. It is associated with recurrent hematuria, nephrolithiasis, and urinary tract infections.

questions.text:
Match each clinical sign associated with Graves' disease to its correct description:

 

Column A:

  1. Von Graefe's sign
  2. Kocher's sign
  3. Stellwag's sign
  4. Griffith's sign

 

Column B:

  1. Reduced blinking frequency
  2. Lid lag of the lower eyelid during upgaze
  3. Frightened or staring appearance
  4. Lid lag of the upper eyelid during downgaze
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-D, 2-C, 3-A, 4-B

 

  • 1-D. Von Graefe's sign: Characterized by the upper eyelid lagging behind the globe when the patient looks downward, leading to a visible scleral strip above the cornea. 
  • 2-C. Kocher's sign: Describes a frightened or staring appearance due to the retraction of the upper eyelid, often seen in hyperthyroidism. 
  • 3-A. Stellwag's sign: Involves infrequent or incomplete blinking, giving the eyes a staring look. 
  • 4-B. Griffith's sign: Refers to the lagging of the lower eyelid on upgaze, resulting in a delay in the lower lid's movement when the eye moves upward

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eyelid signs in Thyroid-associated Ophthalmopathy -

 

  • Dalrymple sign - lid retraction - Most common sign – 92% cases - occurs due to increased sympathomimetic tone causing contraction of Miiller muscle and due to fibrosis
  • Von graefe sign - Lid lag - lower lid moves down slowly on downgaze
  • Kocher's sign - frightened/staring appearance
  • Stellwags sign - reduced blinking frequency
  • Griffith sign - lid lag of lower lid during upgaze
  • Enroth sign - edema of eyelid
  • Gifford’s sign - difficulty in eversion of upper eyelid
  • Rosenbach sign - tremor of closed eyelids
  • Mobius sign - convergence weakness
  • Jellinker sign - abnormal pigmentation of upper eyelid

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with multiple jaw cysts and a history of recurrent basal cell carcinoma. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in a gene that encodes a protein involved in Hedgehog signaling inhibition. Which gene is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PTCH

 

  • The PTCH (Patched) gene encodes a protein that acts as an inhibitor of the Hedgehog signaling pathway. 
  • Mutations in PTCH can lead to unregulated Hedgehog signaling, which is implicated in the development of Gorlin syndrome (nevoid basal cell carcinoma syndrome). 
  • This syndrome is characterized by basal cell carcinomas, medulloblastomas, odontogenic keratocysts (jaw cysts), and other benign tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PTEN: PTEN is a tumor suppressor gene that regulates cell growth by inhibiting the PI3K/AKT pathway. Mutations in PTEN are associated with Cowden syndrome and certain cancers, but not Gorlin syndrome or Hedgehog signaling dysfunction.

 

Option C. SMO: SMO (Smoothened) is a protein that activates the Hedgehog signaling pathway downstream of PTCH. Activating mutations in SMO are seen in some cancers but are not associated with Gorlin syndrome, which specifically involves PTCH mutations.

 

Option D. SHH: SHH (Sonic Hedgehog) is a ligand that activates the Hedgehog pathway by binding to PTCH. While it is critical in embryonic development, SHH mutations are not directly linked to Gorlin syndrome or basal cell carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • PTCH (Patched) is a gene encoding an inhibitor of Hedgehog signaling, and its mutation leads to Gorlin syndrome, characterized by basal cell carcinomas, medulloblastomas, and benign tumors.

questions.text: What is the procedure being shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Billroth II reconstruction

 

The image shows a surgical procedure in which the distal stomach is resected and the gastric remnant is anastomosed to the side of the jejunum, bypassing the duodenum, which is characteristic of Billroth II (gastrojejunostomy) reconstruction.

 

 

Other Options:


Option A. Billroth I reconstruction: Involves gastroduodenostomy, connecting the stomach to the duodenum.


Option C. Braun anastomosis: An additional side-to-side jejunojejunostomy, not visualized here.

 

 

Option D. Roux-en Y gastrojejunostomy: Features a Y-shaped configuration, with separation of the alimentary and biliopancreatic limbs, different from the simple gastrojejunostomy shown.
